articles.headline: Before Birth, Dad’s ID
articles.snippet: Blood tests can determine paternity as early as the eighth week of pregnancy, and without an invasive procedure.
articles.abstract: Blood tests can determine paternity as early as the eighth week of pregnancy, and without an invasive procedure.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is an uncomfortable question that, in today’s world, is often asked by expectant mothers who had more than one male partner at the time they became pregnant. Who is the father?

articles.headline: Self-Interest Meets Mandate
articles.snippet: Whether or not the Supreme Court strikes down the health care law’s individual mandate, the rule might matter less than its advocates believe.
articles.abstract: Whether or not the Supreme Court strikes down the health care law’s individual mandate, the rule might matter less than its advocates believe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within the next few days, the Supreme Court may strike down the provision in the Affordable Care Act requiring every American to buy health insurance. Odds that the justices will reject this measure, the so-called individual mandate, are approaching 80 percent on Intrade, a market where investors can bet on the outcome of pretty much everything.

articles.headline: Mubarak Said to Be in Critical Condition in Egypt Hospital
articles.snippet: Conflicting reports about former President Hosni Mubarak’s health added new volatility to a political and constitutional crisis in the country he once ruled.
articles.abstract: Conflicting reports about former President Hosni Mubarak’s health added new volatility to a political and constitutional crisis in the country he once ruled.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak’s health deteriorated rapidly and he was rushed to a military hospital on Tuesday, adding to the uncertainty gripping the nation as the ousted strongman’s longtime opponents, the Muslim Brotherhood, battled his onetime allies in the military for political power.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Dimon, Testifying Before House, Stays on Message
articles.snippet: Unlike their Senate counterparts, who treated Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase with deference last week, House lawmakers demanded answers about the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.
articles.abstract: Unlike their Senate counterparts, who treated Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase with deference last week, House lawmakers demanded answers about the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, tussled with lawmakers on Tuesday in his second showdown in Washington since JPMorgan, the nation’s largest bank, disclosed a multibillion-dollar trading loss.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Public Workers Face New Rash of Layoffs, Hurting Recovery
articles.snippet: With the economy slowly expanding, state tax revenues have started to recover, but governors and legislatures are keeping a tight rein on spending.
articles.abstract: With the economy slowly expanding, state tax revenues have started to recover, but governors and legislatures are keeping a tight rein on spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies have been slowly adding workers for more than two years. But pink slips are still going out in a crucial area: government.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Venice Beach Bodybuilders Fear Google Is Kicking Sand at Them
articles.snippet: A leasing spree by Google that includes a fabled gym has raised fears of a culture clash in the Los Angeles beach community of Venice, where the likes of Arnold Schwarzenegger have trained.
articles.abstract: A leasing spree by Google that includes a fabled gym has raised fears of a culture clash in the Los Angeles beach community of Venice, where the likes of Arnold Schwarzenegger have trained.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This city’s boardwalk community of Venice has long celebrated its seediness, accepting — embracing, really — the kind of sensory assaults that would faze more conventional places: beachfront bodybuilders, ragamuffin street vendors, tattoo artists, Hare Krishna chanters, skateboarders, drug dealers, gangs, homeless encampments, rowdy tourists, film crews and, more recently, a colony of medical marijuana dispensaries.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: A Phone Bristling With Extras
articles.snippet: The Galaxy S III offers some startlingly creative features, but it may take some time to master.
articles.abstract: The Galaxy S III offers some startlingly creative features, but it may take some time to master.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wow. When Samsung wants to win, it doesn’t kid around.

articles.headline: House Panel’s Vote Steps Up Partisan Fight on Gun Inquiry
articles.snippet: A recommendation along party lines to cite Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for contempt came after President Obama invoked executive privilege to shield documents from disclosure.
articles.abstract: A recommendation along party lines to cite Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for contempt came after President Obama invoked executive privilege to shield documents from disclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A long-simmering fight between Republican lawmakers and the Obama administration sharply escalated on Wednesday, as a Congressional panel recommended that the House of Representatives cite Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for contempt and President Obama asserted executive privilege to shield Justice Department documents from disclosure.
